posts.cooked: I‚Äôm curious how it works, Signal IOS doesn‚Äôt seem to be updated as often as Android? Usually commits are only once a week?

posts.name: Croissant
posts.cooked: Most likely the iOS team is smaller and the android version being out, will receive more fixes as more people report issues with it vs iOS where only the team has access to it in staging.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: They‚Äôre all updated about the same, which is once per week changes are published to production. On rare occasions there have been two in one week to production. The iOS changes tend to be much larger because that version isn‚Äôt as mature as Android.
What do you mean by mature? I thought this version was from the same time as the Android one? Is it more recent? How so?

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Signal started as TextSecure and RedPhone, Android apps that encrypted SMS and phone calls, respectively, in 2010. The two were combined around 2013 to become what is now Signal. An iPhone version followed in the next year or two.

The iPhone team has always been smaller, and went through a bit of a rough patch with senior dev departures over the last ~5 years.

So a historically smaller team, later inception of the iOS app, and team attrition have lead the iOS app to be less mature compared to the Android version.

Read the early posts on Signal >> Blog for more info.
Oh I didn‚Äôt know there wasn‚Äôt as many people for the iOS app, that‚Äôs a shame, hopefully they‚Äôll get more people on board!

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: They have over the last 2 or 3 years. The development progress has picked up a lot since.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: i do want to mention something interesting which is that polls might be a rare instance of a feature arriving on iOS before Android.

posts.name: Tyl89
posts.cooked: I‚Äôve had iOS since the start and signal and I haven‚Äôt seen much development in terms of features but there‚Äôs been some improvements with basic stuff. My contacts on Android have a similar experience and there‚Äôs not much in it from what I can tell but in terms of development across the board it‚Äôs not really noticeable in UX imo - which is a barrier to entry really and getting more on board

Tyl89:

My contacts on Android have a similar experience and there‚Äôs not much in it from what I can tell but in terms of development across the board it‚Äôs not really noticeable in UX imo - which is a barrier to entry really and getting more on board

Could you name some concrete UX issues? Because, albeit on Android, I have zero complaints about that.

posts.name: Metronidazole
posts.cooked: How long will it take for cloud backups to come out after the Android version? I would compile the dev version but then I‚Äôd lose push notifications.
You‚Äôd have to compile the internal builds, they apparently reverted the ‚Äúbeta‚Äù flag for backups, for some reason

posts.name: Metronidazole
posts.cooked: Yeah i‚Äôve already done that but that doesnt have push notifications support.
How does the backup work? Are you using it on the ‚Äúnormal‚Äù servers or only staging?

posts.name: Metronidazole
posts.cooked:
Sorry I haven‚Äôt directly tried the backup feature on iOS specifically as I dont want to risk my data. My build largely just enables linking devices so I can link an iPhone to another phone‚Äôs signal account.

That being said I have indirectly tested it. My primary account is on an android phone which has paid backups enabled. After linking the compiled iOS app to my primary account the backup was automatically restored including all chats and attachments, so that aspect does work already. This is on the live servers, not staging.

Basically I want to move to iPhone but need the backup feature (or device linking) enabled so I can properly transfer from the account from Android to iPhone

Oh wow, I didn‚Äôt know anyone was able to enable linked iPhones. Building the Signal iOS app from source always seemed a bit daunting to me. Could you share how you did it and what you changed exactly? Do I just need to edit the linked phone feature flag and the development team in Xcode? Does the linking UI automatically adapt to phone sized devices or still iPad only?

Also curious if push notifications would work with my paid Apple Developer Program. I know it does for my tweaked Twitter app

posts.name: Metronidazole
posts.cooked:
Yes that‚Äôs exactly what you do. Just change the flag. As for building just follow Build instructions/Signal iOS - Signal Wiki

Change FeatureFlags.swift (cmd shift o)

‚Üí linkedPhones to .production

The ui works fine. I‚Äôm pretty sure the Devs use the feature on their phones.

As for push notifications, I‚Äôve never developed an iOS app so I have no idea. From what I read the answer is no, but I guess if you set up your own push server that handled it then that would work, but obviously that‚Äôs not as trivial as changing a feature flag

What did you change to get push notifications on that modified Twitter app?

Nice! Thanks for the info and the wiki link, I‚Äôll look into that. The timing is perfect if I can make it work, since backups are now available on iOS beta so I‚Äôll also get my history from Android. I may not even need to do a backup, with the link & sync feature from January being enough.

As for push notifications, I don‚Äôt need to do anything. It‚Äôs just that with a paid Apple Developer Program account, you can enable push notification capability when you create a certificate & provisioning profile. Then, you can use an app like Feather to sideload IPAs directly on-device. You just need to keep the same bundle identifier as the official app on the App Store. This is what I do with NeoFreeBird to get Twitter push notifications.

link_counts.title: GitHub - khcrysalis/Feather: Free on-device iOS/iPadOS application manager/installer, using certificates part of the Apple Developer Program.
GitHub - NeoFreeBird/app: A modified Twitter app, with branding reverts, BHTwitter and other QoL modifications.
Signal >> Blog >> A Synchronized Start for Linked Devices

posts.name: Metronidazole
posts.cooked:
Interesting thanks. Let me know if push notifications end up working. I think you need to turn off background app refresh to confirm that.

According to the build instructions you have to change the bundle id so I‚Äôm not sure your method will work

Alright, I tried a bunch of things but in the end, I wasn‚Äôt able to keep the original bundle ID. Xcode throws a lot of errors and the build keeps failing. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs worth putting more effort into fixing those errors, because I also tried to install the official Signal App Store IPA (that you can download from sites like Decrypted App Store or Decrypt.day), which has the original bundle ID, using Feather and it doesn‚Äôt work either: the app installs but crashes immediately. So it‚Äôs probably way more complicated.

Aside from that, I did manage to build and install the app from source by following the wiki guide. The link & sync feature works well, and I got all my message and last 45 days of media. You also don‚Äôt even need to change the feature flag to production since installing with Xcode makes it an internal build.
The app is quite unstable though, and can crash fairly easily depending on what feature you try to use or how far you scroll in a conversation.

Finally, I found one workaround to notify my iPhone that I received a new Signal notification on my Android device. I use a combination of 2 apps: Tasker on Android and Pushcut on iOS.
Pushcut has a backend server that gives you a personal URL that you can ping to send custom push notifications to your iPhone. Tasker lets you intercept the Signal notifications on Android to trigger a request to the Pushcut URL. If you play around with Pushcut, you can customize the notification with a custom icon, sound, text and even a Shortcut so that it opens your Signal Dev app when you tap it.

I think this is the best we can do until linked iPhones are officially enabled in production.
